label: Comparison
Arg1_RawText: In an Oct. 19 review of "The Misanthrope" at Chicago's Goodman Theatre ("Revitalized Classics Take the Stage in Windy City," Leisure & Arts), the role of Celimene, played by Kim Cattrall, was mistakenly attributed to Christina Haag
Arg2_RawText: Ms. Haag plays Elianti

Arg1_RawText: BELL INDUSTRIES Inc. increased its quarterly to 10 cents from seven cents a share
Arg2_RawText: The new rate will be payable Feb. 15

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: Solo woodwind players have to be creative if they want to work a lot, because their repertoire and audience appeal are limited
Arg2_RawText: The oboist Heinz Holliger has taken a hard line about the problem: He commissions and splendidly interprets fearsome contemporary scores and does some conducting, so he doesn't have to play the same Mozart and Strauss concertos over and over again

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: Richard Stoltzman has taken a gentler, more audience-friendly approach
Arg2_RawText: Years ago, he collaborated with the new music gurus Peter Serkin and Fred Sherry in the very countercultural chamber group Tashi, which won audiences over to dreaded contemporary scores like Messiaen's "Quartet for the End of Time

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: and now goes on the road with piano, bass, a slide show, and a repertoire that ranges from light classical to light jazz to light pop, with a few notable exceptions
Arg2_RawText: Just the thing for the Vivaldi-at-brunch set, the yuppie audience that has embraced New Age as its very own easy listening

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: But you can't dismiss Mr. Stoltzman's music or his motives as merely commercial and lightweight
Arg2_RawText: He believes in what he plays, and he plays superbly

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: He believes in what he plays, and he plays superbly
Arg2_RawText: His recent appearance at the Metropolitan Museum, dubbed "A Musical Odyssey," was a case in point

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: His recent appearance at the Metropolitan Museum, dubbed "A Musical Odyssey," was a case in point
Arg2_RawText: It felt more like a party, or a highly polished jam session with a few friends, than a classical concert

label: Temporal
Arg1_RawText: Clad in his trademark black velvet suit, the soft-spoken clarinetist announced that his new album, "Inner Voices," had just been released, that his family was in the front row, and that it was his mother's birthday, so he was going to play her favorite tune from the record
Arg2_RawText: He launched into Saint-Saens's "The Swan" from "Carnival of the Animals," a favorite encore piece for cellists, with lovely, glossy tone and no bite

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: And so it went through the first half: an ingeniously chosen potpourri of pieces, none longer than five minutes, none that would disturb or challenge a listener
Arg2_RawText: Mr. Stoltzman introduced his colleagues: Bill Douglas, pianist/bassoonist/composer and an old buddy from Yale, and jazz bassist Eddie Gomez

label: Temporal
Arg1_RawText: Mr. Stoltzman introduced his colleagues: Bill Douglas, pianist/bassoonist/composer and an old buddy from Yale, and jazz bassist Eddie Gomez
Arg2_RawText: An improvisational section was built around pieces by Mr. Douglas, beginning with "Golden Rain," a lilting, laid-back lead in to the uptempo "Sky," which gave Mr. Stoltzman the opportunity to wail in a high register and show off his fleet fingers

Arg2_RawText: Bach's "Air" followed

Arg2_RawText: Mr. Stoltzman tied the composer in by proclaiming him "the great improviser of the 18th century

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: The end of the first half, however, brought what the standing-room-only crowd seemed to be waiting for: the pop singer Judy Collins, who appears on "Inner Voices
Arg2_RawText: Glamorous and pure-voiced as ever, Ms. Collins sang Joni Mitchell's "For Free" -- about an encounter with a street-corner clarinetist, to which Mr. Stoltzman contributed a clarinet obligatto -- and Mr. Douglas's lush setting of a Gaelic blessing, "Deep Peace

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: The end of the first half, however, brought what the standing-room-only crowd seemed to be waiting for: the pop singer Judy Collins, who appears on "Inner Voices." Glamorous and pure-voiced as ever, Ms. Collins sang Joni Mitchell's "For Free" -- about an encounter with a street-corner clarinetist, to which Mr. Stoltzman contributed a clarinet obligatto -- and Mr. Douglas's lush setting of a Gaelic blessing, "Deep Peace." "Deep Peace" also featured a slide show of lovely but predictable images of clouds, beaches, deserts, sunsets, etc
Arg2_RawText: It was all too mellow to be believed, but they probably would have gotten away with it, had they not felt compelled to add Ms. Collins's signature tune, "Amazing Grace," and ask for audience participation

label: Contingency
Arg1_RawText: It was all too mellow to be believed, but they probably would have gotten away with it, had they not felt compelled to add Ms. Collins's signature tune, "Amazing Grace," and ask for audience participation
Arg2_RawText: That went over the permissible line for warm and fuzzy feelings

label: Expansion
Arg1_RawText: Was this why some of the audience departed before or during the second half?Or was it because Ms. Collins had gone
Arg2_RawText: Either way it was a pity

label: Contingency
Arg1_RawText: Mr. Stoltzman must have worried that his audience might not be able to take it
Arg2_RawText: He warned us in advance that "New York Counterpoint" lasts 11 1/2 minutes

label: Temporal
Arg1_RawText: He also unfortunately illustrated this intricate, jazzy tapestry with Mr. Pearson's images, this time of geometric or repeating objects, in a kitschy mirroring of the musical structure that was thoroughly distracting from Mr. Reich's piece and Mr. Stoltzman's elegant execution of it
Arg2_RawText: The rest of the concert was more straight jazz and mellow sounds written by Charlie Parker, Ornette Coleman, Bill Douglas and Eddie Gomez, with pictures for the Douglas pieces
